Administration.text:
Type:
Antidote
Dosage Forms:
Routes of Administration: IV
Common Trade Names:

Adult_Dosing.text:
Major bleeding due to unfractionated heparin:
1 mg IV for every 100 units of heparin infused in past 3h
Do not infuse faster than 50mg/10min
If it has been >30min since last heparin injection, 0.5mg may be sufficient
Give slowly over 1-3min; do not exceed 50mg in any 10 minute period (
anaphylaxis
risk)
Because half-life is short (7 min) may require second treatment
Major bleeding due to low-molecular-weight heparin:
Protamine is less effective for bleeding from LMWH than it is with heparin-induced bleeds
Enoxaparin:
1 mg IV for every 1 mg enoxaparin administered in past 8h
Dalteparin:
1 mg IV for every 100 anti-Xa international units of dalteparin

Pediatric_Dosing.text: Safety/Efficacy not well established in pediatrics, but unofficial suggested dosing similar to adult dosing

Special_Populations.text:
Pregnancy Rating
: C
Lactation risk
: Infant risk cannot be ruled out
Renal dosing: no adjustment
Hepatic dosing: no adjustment

Serious.text:
Anaphylaxis
(0.2% of patients), anaphylactoid reaction
Circulatory collapse, capillary leak, bradyarrhythmia, hypotension
Pulmonary edema

Anaphylaxis
(0.2% of patients), anaphylactoid reaction
Circulatory collapse, capillary leak, bradyarrhythmia, hypotension
Pulmonary edema

,

Unfractionated heparin
,
